title: 108_s2205
content: There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so the curr_chunk cannot be summarized at this time. The Congress acknowledges that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate without excessive taxes or charges, has been compliant with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997, and has made significant progress towards democracy since gaining independence in 1991. Since gaining independence in 1991, Ukraine has made significant progress towards democracy and a free-market economy. It is in full compliance with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997 and is committed to developing a system of governance in accordance with human rights principles. Ukraine, as an OSCE member state, is dedicated to developing governance aligned with human rights principles outlined in the Helsinki Final Act. The country has made strides in meeting international standards, notably in recent Parliamentary elections. Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments in its recent Parliamentary elections, but significant shortcomings remain, including issues with election laws, interference by public authorities, and allegations of intimidation against opposition figures and voters. Ukraine's progress in meeting international commitments in recent Parliamentary elections is marred by shortcomings in election laws, interference by public authorities, and allegations of intimidation against opposition figures and voters. Additionally, as an OSCE participating state, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities. Legislation has been enacted to protect against incitement to violence based on ethnicity or religion. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on ethnicity or religion, including anti-Semitism. The country is committed to ensuring equality for national minorities and freedom of religion, as well as combating racial and ethnic intolerance and hatred. Ukraine has engaged in efforts to combat ethnic and religious intolerance by cooperating with US NGOs and continuing the restitution of religious properties. Ukraine is continuing efforts to combat ethnic and religious intolerance by cooperating with US NGOs and restoring religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era. Ukraine is developing a legislative framework to revive national and religious minority groups by restoring properties confiscated during the Soviet era. They have received normal trade relations treatment after a bilateral trade agreement with the US and are progressing towards accession to the World Trade Organization. Ukraine is making progress towards joining the World Trade Organization, with key issues to resolve including access for US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, export incentives, and customs reform. Ukraine has enacted protections for labor rights and committed to respecting freedom of the press as a participating state of the OSCE. Ukraine has positive relations with neighboring countries and aims for European integration while ensuring democracy and prosperity for its citizens. Ukraine respects freedom of the press despite ongoing infringements. It has positive relations with neighboring countries, aims for European integration, and cooperates with the United States in peacekeeping operations and the fight against terrorism. SEC. 2. TERMINATION OF APPLICATION OF TITLE IV OF THE TRADE ACT OF 1974 TO UKRAINE. The President may determine that title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 should no longer apply to Ukraine and proclaim the extension of permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The President may terminate the application of Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Ukraine and extend permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining a comprehensive engagement with Ukraine, including urging Ukraine to fulfill its commitments as an OSCE member, ensuring free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, and enforcing laws against discrimination and violence. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of Ukraine ensuring free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, enforcing laws against discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of Ukraine ensuring free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, enforcing laws against discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. Additionally, working with Ukraine to improve in various areas, support efforts in enacting and enforcing intellectual property rights, and ensure quick resolution of issues. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of Ukraine ensuring free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, enforcing laws against discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. Additionally, supporting Ukraine's efforts in enacting and enforcing intellectual property rights, ensuring quick resolution of trade disputes, and monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine, providing assistance to NGOs and human rights groups, and establishing annual discussions with Ukraine on these issues. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The reports required by sections 102(b) and 203 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 shall include an assessment of certain issues. SEC. 5. CONTINUED ENJOYMENT OF RIGHTS UNDER THE JUNE 23, 1992, BILATERAL TRADE AGREEMENT. The trade agreement between the United States and Ukraine, in force since June 23, 1992, allows the US to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 applies to Ukraine as it does to China, as long as the agreement remains valid. Congressional oversight over WTO accession negotiations is addressed in Section 6. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced in Congress within 30 days, it may impact the agreement. Within 15 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession, a report outlining the provisions must be sent to Congress. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced within 30 days, it will be considered according to specific procedures. Section 154(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 outlines the process for considering a resolution of disapproval by Congress regarding international agreements. Section 154(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 outlines the process for considering a resolution of disapproval by Congress regarding international agreements, specifically defining a "resolution of disapproval" as a joint resolution of the two Houses expressing Congress's dissatisfaction with the terms of an agreement between the United States and Ukraine on Ukraine's accession to the World Trade Organization. The Trade Act of 1974 outlines procedures for considering resolutions of disapproval regarding international agreements. The sense of Congress is that the agreement between the US and Ukraine on Ukraine's accession to the WTO does not advance US interests. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced by any Member of the House. Procedures for considering resolutions of disapproval involve introduction by any Member of the House, referral to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules, and no amendments by either Committee. In the House, resolutions of disapproval are introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules, and cannot be amended by either Committee. In the Senate, resolutions may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. In the Senate, resolutions may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. The Trade Act of 1974 applies committee discharge and floor consideration rules to resolutions of disapproval to the same extent as resolutions under the Act. Subsection (b) is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and Senate. The Trade Act of 1974 applies committee discharge and floor consideration rules to resolutions of disapproval to the same extent as resolutions under the Act. Subsection (b) is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and Senate, deemed a part of their respective rules. The Trade Act of 1974 applies committee discharge and floor consideration rules to resolutions of disapproval to the same extent as resolutions under the Act. Subsection (b) is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and Senate, deemed a part of their respective rules. The procedures outlined in the subsection supersede other rules to the extent of inconsistency and allow each House to change its rules regarding procedures at any time.
